reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing pinball, off and on, for over 50 years, and I've played hundreds of tables. I've played every table by both major companies on Steam to the tune of many thousands of games, but all that is pretty much in the past, because I have discovered Pro Pinball Ultra's Timeshock" table. Most days it’s the only pinball I play.

In the 35 days since Timeshock was released 0n 1/27/16

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT: Forced to run on Low settings before my upgrade. Now, Max settings run GLORIOUSLY. If you have a high end rig, you definitely won't be disappointed with the light settings and sequences.

Original: Don't ever question the Pro Pinball series. Especially Timeshock. Even the original series still holds up excellently today -- amazing ball physics, rulesets, and audio.

This version has been made even better than before. Pro Pinball is now more graphically enhanced, especially around dazzling light shows. And even if it's still in Early Access (more features to come, as stated in the Store description), this is a must-buy. And yes, more tables are coming.

Got my first ULTRA Jackpot on this version. Without the need of ball control.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In terms of user experience when you're getting started, this is really very much Early Access".

But the actual pinball table itself? Wow
date: it is an absolute work of art. The lighting
hoursPlayed: the physics - it's all spot on. It feels right. This feels like a real pinball table in a way most other video pinball just doesn't. Suddenly
voteText: as I began to play

votesHelpful:
to do those old beloved tables justice in a far more accurate preservation. Barnstorm Games' love for pinball is present in every minute detail. It's there in the travel of the ball. It's there in the gentle reflections of light. It's there in the click of the flipper. The ka-chunk of the targets.

Even the physics in the in-table video mode DMD game are better than I would expect from a pinball table!

If you love pinball

Timeshock! is the pinball that survived nearly 20 years. I'm sure that game is responsible for many smashed keyboards and controllers. Well, now is the good time for some vengeance: you can take the glass off, grab the ball and shove it into whatever hole you like! Screaming in joy is optional, but very recommended.
Finally nailed a 10-way first time in my life!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is okay, but in the end was not worth the wait in it's current state.

First of all, the Kickstarter for this game was a disaster. Their promise was that with the money earned by the Kickstarter, they would be able to speed up development. This was in the end of 2013. Yes, 2013. They promised it would be finished at the start of 2014. With barely any communication they just contineud to postpone the release without actually telling anyone about the progress of the game.

Next, the optimisation is very bad. The game might look pretty, but does not run well at all on any standard gaming pc. Also the angles of the tables are not changeble. And now the UI is actually on top of the table, the table looks very small and is not comfortable to play on (for me at least).

I hope they will still be able to improve and optimise performance of the game and also add the angles THE ORIGINAL GAME had. But with this slow progress, the game probably won't be out of 'early access' before 2020.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the definitive version of the definitive Pinball game.
Nothing compares to Pro Pinball in terms of good table design, realistic physics simulation and overall high-quality Pinball experience.
Timeshock was already great back in the day, and the new, remade version only makes it even better.
The graphics are amazing, and it feels just like a real Pinball table would, in a way other pinball simulators just can't emulate. You can really feel the attention to detail and the love for Pinball the Pro Pinball team have in every inch of the table. Just play any other pinball game out there and then play this one, and you'll know what I mean.
The design of the table itself is also fantastic. There is so much to do and to discover, that it feels like a real adventure, and it'll keep you playing for hours and hours. A bit on the difficult side, but that's part of the charm.

It's still in Early Access, so a few of the promised features are missign, specially some of the view angles and a decent interface for rebinding controls, but nothing that detracts from the main experience.

tl;dr - If you enjoy Pinball games, then this is a MUST BUY. It really doesn't get any better than that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

without a doubt one of the greatest pinball simulations ever made, now in 4k.

fair warning, though: it will kick your butt. i've been playing this for about 15 years now and I haven't made it to the Timeshock Frenzy on default settings a single time. but it's never not fun to play - even if you don't get to the end, you will almost certainly play through a well-designed set of missions and features, some fun multiballs, the brilliant Video Mode (which could probably be spun off into its own little runner game) and a damn fine light show, which now looks better than ever.

if you love pinball, play it. if you enjoy the odd spot of pinball, check it out and I'm sure you'll fall in love yourself.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An immaculate update to an all-time classic.

The original 1997 Timeshock! still looks and runs great today, despite being almost 20 years old, but the much improved reflections, dynamic lighting and the support for larger resolutions and modern operating systems makes this £10 update completely worth it. Those familiar with the original game will feel right at home, because although the ball physics are vastly improved, the table still feels exactly the same.

Glass-Off mode is a welcome addition too, as it lets you practice tricky shots and combos, and allows you to advance through difficult missions just by clicking the ball and flicking it where it needs to go (great for when you're curious about some of the later missions but lack the skill to reach them legitimately!).

Performance is excellent; I've never dipped below 60 FPS, even during intense multiballs. The game generally hovers at around 120-150 FPS on an FX 8350 and HD7970 at 1440p and 4x MSAA when a single ball is in play. I've seen it go as low 75 FPS when there are seven balls on the table.

In the future I'd like to see options added for table tilt, flipper strength and level of wear (some of my favourite features to play with in Big Race USA), and of course, more tables! I'd be very excited to see The Web, Big Race USA and Fantastic Journey recieve the same treatment as Timeshock! Maybe a brand new table as well? Fingers crossed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So here it is - the Ultra edition of Pro Pinball: Timeshock. If the differences aren't immediately apparent, remember that's only because the 1997 original was so far ahead of the curve. The lighting effects in this version have to be seen to be believed - static screnshots don't really do them justice. Every piece of wire, every screw, every element is lit up by the hundreds of lights on the table and you can see every one of them reflecting and reacting to what's going on, it's *beautiful*. You'd swear they'd mounted a camera on a physical table and filmed it (at very, very high resolution!)

The static camera is not an issue for me, although it's a pity there's only one choice of viewing angle and no cabinet mode (both allegedly to be added in future updates). Also, the physics are the same as the original version - not that the ball motion is especially bad, in fact not the worst on the market even 15 years later, but it would be nice to see some improvements in the state of the art.

Of course a lot of people will complain that there's only one table in the game, it's true, but Timeshock has the deepest and best ruleset of any pinball sim I've seen. Better that than twenty-five copy-paste games with cosmetic differences but near-identical gameplay. If you have even the least interest in Pinball there's no excuse for not giving Timeshock a go.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I used to play Timeshock(on dos) with my father when I was growing up. Getting to play this table again is just incredible.

The visuals are pristine. Seriously, I hope others follow suit in the pre-rendered-to-layers graphical approach of this table, as the edge clarity, lighting, translucency, and detail surpass what's possible with real-time rendering as to be laughable. The physicality this yields the table is unmatched.

In terms of gameplay, this remains one of the most interesting, deep, and well crafted 'narrative' pinball tables ever made. The soundtrack aids this tremendously as well. There are few pinball tables that manage to create the experience of a dramatic journey, and Timeshock certainly does.

I own this on all its available platforms, play it in the can on my phone, play it in vertical-format on my PC now. (seriously, if your monitor can do portrait mode DO IT)

If you love pinball, buying this is a no-brainer. Worth every cent.

Current Early Access State: Needs custom control mapping, a true fullscreen mode. Will update review when these occur.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Timeshock is still the very best pinball game for PC. If you like pinball or are just even slightly interested in it, buy it now.

This is a graphically updated version of the excellent pinball simulation Timeshock from 1997. The Pro Pinball series was the absolute top of PC pinball back then and has not been surpassed since. This updated version does the game justice. The updates include higher resolution, better lighting and portrait mode, which of course works great for pinball.

The table itself is unchanged, which is a good thing. It remains one of the best tables I have ever played virtual or real. The table design is perfect, the shots have exactly the right difficulty and feel very satisfying. The ruleset is very deep, there are an incredible number of modes, super modes, wizard modes, frenzys, manias, video mode... etc. which will keep all but the most seasoned pinball veteran occupied forever. (I have played this table for almost 20 years and never reached the super wizard mode in normal play.) The modes and table elements all interact to form a path and a story. Still, the table keeps a simple elegance and is not overwhelming, even for beginners.

The updated graphics are gorgeous, the light show at the beginning of the time travel mode is one of the best in any pinball machine. The sound and music were not upgraded, but still do the job nicely. The guitar music soundtrack is a matter of taste, I personally like it a lot. There are different tracks for different game situations and modes and they fit very nicely.

This is a simulation of a real world pinball table, there even is an operator's menu to tweak the internal settings of the machine. That also means it is quite difficult, especially compared to the more arcady games like Pinball FX and Pinball Arcade. The table is unforgiving, but never unfair. Through the operator's menu the game can be made easier, but for me the standard settings work well.

There are a few things that are still missing: UI to change default controls, controller support and more table views. I was the most disappointed that they have not improved the physics to at least the level of the later Pro Pinball games „Big Race USA” and “Fantastic Journey” yet, I hope this is coming soon. The current physics model is from the original game. It is by no means bad and feels very real. It is in every way superior to other games like Pinball Arcade. But the physics of the later Pro Pinball games are even better and I was hoping that 20 years later and with superior hardware, this could have been taken up another notch.

These things are promised, unfortunately Barnstorm Games has not exactly convinced with speed on what is a mere upgrade and has struggled through 2 years of development. I hope they can improve their development process and dedication to the PC platform, implement the missing features soon and hopefully even upgrade the other old tables and design new ones.

While the price of this game is higher than other tables on the market, it is absolutely justified by the superior simulation. The table design is on a completely different level than Pinball FX tables and the realism and graphics easily and clearly surpass Pinball Arcade. This table makes these other pinball games look bad by comparison. It would be amazing if the Pinball Arcade developers could reach the same level of detail and realism. The table design can absolutely compare to some of the best real tables out there, so it is not surprising that there is a company working on a real world version of Timeshock.

I have been playing the original for almost 20 years and I know I will play this for at least as long. For an early access game it is already very much playable and I can recommend it highly to both pinball experts and beginners.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's early to write a review for 'Pro Pinball Ultra,' as it's not finished, so I'll write a small one for Timeshock instead.

One of the best pinball tables ever designed I'd say; I think that's fair. As far as virtual/digital pinball goes, I think it is only beaten by one table: Fantastic Journey. FJ had the last and best physics that Barnstorm created, but I think a lot of the rubber on the table was firmer too (less bouncy) and maybe that's why I prefer it.

Writing a review is tricky here: I'd give the original Timeshock 10/10. The score would be due to the table design AND the implementation (the physics, the views given, the virtual DMD, the soundtrack, everything about it). But lots of that stuff in not done for this version of Timeshock yet, and the physics will be changed (note that it was stated that there would be an option included to allow play with the original physics; not sure how leaderboards will deal with this though).

So it's tricky to review 'Pro Pinball Ultra' you see.

Personally, I expect Barnstorm to put in all the time needed to make it as good as it can possibly be: I have that faith. I feel safe recommending the game that will be, but as I write this review the original 'finished' Timeshock is better.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI did not see anything great about this game in the amount of time I had to play it. However I can only play it for a few seconds before my computer crashes... in that time, as i looked over the game I didn't see anything that was very interesting. The only thing i liked about the game is that it offers an option to play it at 2560 x 1440, so i can load it on my monitor in portrait style, which makes the play area a lot larger than on a landscape oriented monitor and so there is no need for the game to alter the perspective of the table as you play. This was the first pinball game I bought for the pc and thought that maybe my computer wasn't powerful enough to run pinball games but then i took a chance and bought a bunch of pinball games from pinball arcade and i was able to play for hours without a problem. I have a core i7 3.4 GHz cpu with a firepro v7900 video card. Based on the fact that i am not able to play the game for more than a few seconds, and what I did see while playing it wasn't interesting to me, I should probably give it a one star out of five, but since it has the option to play at 2560 x 1440, which is an excellent idea, I will give it a generous two stars...also if the game worked for more than a few seconds, it's possible I would have discovered more about the game that I liked.
